Title: Max Ernst, Flowers on a Yellow Ground (1929)
Blurb: But the real action is the yellow shock of Max Ernst’s flowers

Title: Paul Delvaux , Landscape with Lanterns (1959)
Blurb: An airless dream scene that feels alien yet familiar at once.

Title: Franz Sedlacek, Mountain Landscape with Automobile (1931)
Blurb: I was struck by a description of Sedlacek’s paintings as “representing nostalgic landscapes of the soul,” and their crispness gives his scenes a fairytale quality—which is odd because don’t memory and nostalgia tend be blurry?

Title: Anselm Feuerbach, Medea (1873)
Blurb: The sorrowful grey skin, a stillness threatened by the mad violence across a vase.

Title: Moser’s exhibition posters
Blurb: Perhaps the best use of stark geometries. But why do hard lines and perfect circles from 1902 feel so futuristic?

Title: Gustav Klimt
Blurb: his rendering of Judith with an expression so seductive, relaxed, and defiant that the severed head she cradles becomes an afterthought.

Title: Tobias Pils
Blurb: Figures hunched in the murk,  maybe a two-and-a-half legged woman. Others squeeze their hair and still others fondle eggs. Somehow all the white space around these images becomes sinisiter, that this is *all* Pils wants to show us.

Title: Mammo Roella, La Scaermo (1965)
Blurb: A false childhood memory of a drive-in movie. An adult memory of a television flickering in a sad motel room.

Title: Robert Bechtle, Berkley Pines (1976)
Blurb: Painting as a photograph. You can feel the morning glare of the sun, the crisp spring air around the family heat.

Title: Laslo Moholy-Nagy, Composition Q VIII (1922)
Blurb: There’s something so confident and cool about Moholy-Nagy’s Composition Q VIII. I think it’s the visual hiccup between the transluscent white panel and the jet black cross.

Title: Pieter Bruegel, The Fight between Carnival and Lent (1559)
Blurb: Some big-budget Bruegel at the Kunsthistorische Museum: the high drama of the Procession to Calvary and the tower of Babel. Scenes of peasant feats, Solomon’s suicide, and hunters tromping through the snow. But most of all I was struck by The Fight Between Carnival and Lent, a scene of utter derangement that captures the blurred line between the sacred and profane.

Title: Caravaggio, Saint Jerome in His Study (1606)
Blurb: John Berger has said Caravaggio’s darkness “smells of candles, over-ripe melons, damp washing to be hung out the next day.” To me, it feels like the purple-black thoughts that burble within the midnight brain. And in this darkness, Jerome no longer belongs to history or dogma but to the silence he sought in the desert.

Title: Lee Ufan, Relatum-Silence (2010)
Blurb: At Naoshima, I was unexpectedly moved by a hunched boulder that appeared to pray before a glossy sheet of metal.
